Princeton Ky
Dec 24 1863
Gov. Thos. E. Bramlette
Dear Sir

Although almost unknown to you, permit me to make a suggestion in regard to the condition of this section of the state just now. The 3rd Ky Cavalry a very efficient ^Regt,^ which since March has been stationed at Hopkinsville and afforded protection to this section, has lately been ordered to report at Nashville for duty in part The 48th infantry has gone to Russellville and this section lying below Russellville and South of Henderson County, is left entirely exposed to Guerrillas & robbers, who have already ruined the state West of Tennessee River. We will assuredly be plundered & ravaged if ^or^ not murdered, if not protected promptly.

Our only hope now is in home Guards. There are some 15 or 20 young and efficient young men in this and Trigg who have been in service in the 3rd Ky Cav. this Fall but discharged as we understand however the mustering officer would not service them. There are also a few of the 8th Ky Cav. who were discharged at the expiration of their term, who lately routed Bob Martin on his return from a raid into Ky.
This form can be immediately counted and made efficient by giving commpanies to each of the most efficient men among them.

We therefor ask you to appoint Thos. Henderson Captain of a company of Home Guards If you do so in an that a protection will ever be afforded by prompt action
is necessary. permit us to say that we have seen nothing since the Rebellion that meets our views so completely as your messages

Respcectfully
C. D. Bradley
A. Reynolds
R, B, Ratliff
J H Garrett
E P,, Campbell
Comths Atty
J. N. Turner
Citizens in regard to organizing Company for Home protection

(ans Dec 30-63 see letter book)
Recd I. G. O. Dec 29th 1863
